['한국과 중남미: 변화하는 세계 속의 발전의 동반자 보고서는 한국과 중남미 간의 협력과 파트너십을 촉진하고, 두 지역 간의 무역과 투자를 촉진하여 새로운 기회를 창출하는 데 중점을 둔다. 이 보고서는 한-중남미 무역 및 혁신 포럼을 위해 준비된 문서로, 미주개발은행과 한국 기획재정부가 주최하고, 한국수출입은행과 대한무역투자진흥공사가 공동으로 조직한 포럼의 성공을 기념하는 것이다. 보고서는 무역 및 투자에서의 최신 동향을 검토하고, 한국과 중남미가 새로운 기회를 창출할 잠재력을 강조한다. 이를 통해 한-중남미 파트너십이 양 지역 간의 더 깊고 강력한 유대 관계의 기초를 마련하고, 무역과 투자에 새로운 활력을 불어넣을 수 있다는 점을 강조한다.']

['이러한 입장은 한국의 경쟁력에 대한 아르헨티나와 브라질 산업계의 우려 를 반영한 것으로, 현재 한국의 높은 보호 수준에 의해 어려움을 겪고 있는 농산품과 식품의 잠재적 수출 기 회를 무시한 것이다.', '2009년 한국과 MERCOSUR는 무역투자진흥협의체를 설립했다. 2016년', '6월 두', '번째 회의에서 양측은 각 당사국의 무역 정책에 대한 관련 정보를 교환하고 무역협정 체결을 위한 협상 지침을 수립하는 예비회의를 시작하기로 결정했다.', '2017년 초에는 공동선언을 통해 예비회의가 마무리되고 무역 협상을 시작할 준비가 되었음을 발표했다.21 아르헨티나와 브라질 산업 부문의 저항에도 불구하고, 한국과 MERCOSUR 간의 무역 협상은 2018년']

['The book "Bridges for Development: Policies and Institutions for Trade and Integration" provides a compelling analysis of Latin American trade and integration, shedding light on the pivotal role of effective policy design, institutional frameworks, and public-private partnerships in shaping the region's economic landscape. This comprehensive work delves into the historical context of Latin American trade, offering valuable insights for policymakers, researchers, and practitioners in international development. It addresses the challenges and opportunities faced by Latin American countries, emphasizing the impact of incomplete institutional reforms and the need for effective coordination between government bodies and the private sector.

Furthermore, the book discusses the role of competition policy in the context of international firms and the potential impact of their actions on policy reforms. It also delves into the implications of cross-border mergers and acquisitions, highlighting the potential distortions in resource allocation and the challenges associated with simultaneous national merger reviews. The summary emphasizes the need for a global perspective in evaluating the impact of national merger reviews on the allocation of resources.

Overall, the executive summary provides a comprehensive overview of the book's key themes, offering valuable insights into the complexities of Latin American trade and integration and the implications for policy and institutional frameworks.']

['There are two decisionmaking bodies beneath the Council: the Mercosur Group—the main executive body composed of officials from the four governments—and a trade commission to review trade policy and examine complaints.', "Other institutions are a Parliamentary Commission to represent the four countries' legislatures, a Consultative Forum for private sector businesses and trade unions, and a purely administrative Mercosur Secretariat based in Montevideo.", "An annex to the Protocol sets out the trade commission's complaint procedure: The four partners will attempt to solve complaints and trade disputes through consensus.", 'If there is no consensus or a decision is not upheld, the complainant can initiate proceedings under the 1991 Protocol of Brasilia.', 'A tribunal with one judge from each of the countries in dispute and a third independent judge decides the cases.1', 'Copyright © by the Inter-American Development Bank.', 'All rights reserved.', 'For more information visit our website: www.iadb.org/pub This minimalist institutional arrangement has repeatedly shown its weaknesses.', 'In a recent evaluation of Mercosur, Bouzas (2001) points to many deficiencies at the implementation stage, especially since 1995.', 'In the area of nontariff barriers, little progress is reported.', 'The implementation of common trade policies has also lagged.', 'The GET has only been partially implemented, and many "temporary" exceptions have been authorized.', 'The deepening agenda agreed upon in Montevideo in December 1995 has made virtually no progress.', 'In April 2000, the presidents of the member states pledged to relaunch the deepening project.', 'They agreed to harmonize economic statistics and set common targets for inflation and public debt.', 'They signed a deal to bring automobiles into the Mercosur agreement; however, sugar, another contentious item, was not included.', 'Overall, progress has been excruciatingly slow.', 'Also notable is that the leaders failed to agree on a common policy on antidumping.']

['The chapter "Regional Integration and Territorial Development in Latin America" offers a compelling exploration of the complex interplay between regional integration and territorial development in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC). It delves into the challenges and opportunities arising from regional integration agreements and their impact on spatial development and economic disparities within the region. The authors emphasize the need for a holistic approach that connects global governance and national policies to address asymmetries and promote equitable socioeconomic integration into the global economy. The chapter also explores the policy framework, local governance, and the local effects of globalization, offering a dynamic and insightful narrative on the factors influencing territorial development in the context of regional integration. The authors argue that the capacity of LAC countries, particularly smaller, less-developed ones, to benefit from expanded trade opportunities depends on how asymmetries in size and economic development are addressed. They highlight the importance of preserving margins of flexibility to adopt active productive development policies to improve competitiveness and flexibility in managing the capital account as an instrument of macroeconomic regulation. Additionally, the chapter emphasizes the importance of trade liberalization, mobilization of financial resources, and increased labor mobility to foster income convergence and promote sustainable economic growth within the region.']

expected_output: The members of Mercosur are Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, and Uruguay. These countries form the core of the regional trade bloc, which aims to promote economic integration and cooperation among its members. Additionally, Venezuela was also a member but has been suspended since 2016 due to political issues. Bolivia is in the process of becoming a full member as well.[Source 5]

input.question: What does Brazil need to do to address its fiscal situation?

contexts.text: ['The collapse of public investment to levels close to 2 percent of GDP (central government, subnational and state enterprises) is a corollary of the fiscal difficulties, contributing to the country’s infrastructure deficit and its poor quality.', 'Brazil has a set of fiscal rules that constrains government spending at the federal and subnational levels.', 'Most of them were set before the current fiscal crisis, the government expenditure ceiling being a notable exception.', 'A question this paper will try to address is whether those fiscal rules are to blame for the collapse of public investment or alternatively, the sharp public investment contraction rather reflected the lack of fiscal discipline and uncontrolled fiscal expansion.', 'A further question is whether it is possible to redesign the fiscal framework with alternative fiscal rules which would support the necessary fiscal adjustment and preserve public investment.', 'An important constraint on the fiscal adjustment strategy is the fact that the tax burden in Brazil is relatively high for a middle-income country, having reached 35 percent of GDP in 2019.', 'Since further increases in taxes are likely to negatively affect private investment, fiscal adjustment must basically rely on curbing expenditures.', 'About two-thirds of public investments (excluding from state enterprises) are undertaken by subnational governments.', 'Thus, the relation between fiscal rules and public investment must involve the study of the subnational fiscal framework and outcomes, which is no small task given that Brazil has 27 states and 5,570 municipalities.', 'Brazilian subnational entities are facing a fiscal crisis, with more than half of the states with insufficient cash to pay their short-term liabilities.', 'As a consequence, states have also reduced substantially their investment, with few exceptions.', 'Comparing the first semester of new governors’ terms in 2019 with the first semester of 2015— both the beginning of a new political cycle—there is a 52.5 percent reduction in states’ investment.', '3']

['Facing the need to accept a long - term fiscal adjustment , the central government has been severely constrained by the obligation to transfer to lower levels a large proportion of the revenue from personal income , profit , and excise taxes on industrialized products , knowing in advance that', 'any transfer will be immediately spent by state and local governments .', 'This drain seriously reduces the effectiveness of the overall fiscal effort and thus the possibilities of stabilization policy.17 This , in turn , has led to a search for exotic federal taxes , capable of generating resources not shared with state and local governments , which has meant a further', 'deterioration of the quality of the tax system .', 'Most state governments in Brazil have become clearly overindebted.', 'And the federal government has been pressed hard by state governors to "solve" their debt problems.', 'Facing the possibility of rejection by Congress of the fiscal adjustment package submitted in late 1991, the federal government finally agreed to include in the package an Copyright © by the Inter-American Development Bank.', 'All rights reserved.', 'For more information visit our website: www.iadb.org/pub 17 See Werneck (1992) for a fuller analysts of the present difficulties imposed by fiscal federalism on stabilization policy in Brazil.', "140 EN ROUTE TO MODERN GROWTH ample rescheduling of the states' debts.", 'The part of the debt owed either to the federal government or to any of its financial institutions would be rescheduled to be paid over 20 years.', 'The state bonds held by the private investors, which pay a very high interest rate, would be exchanged for lower-cost federal bonds.', 'This new legislation only established the guidelines that bilateral rescheduling agreements between each state and the federal government should follow.', "To avoid the inducement for a large future increase in the states' deficits (the moral hazard problem) the federal government succeeded in including in the debt-rescheduling legislation a restraint on the states' new debt issues."]

['"En Route to Modern Growth: Latin America in the 1990s Essays in Honor of Carlos Diaz-Alejandro" is a compelling collection of essays that offers a deep dive into Latin America\'s economic development during a pivotal decade. Edited by Gustav Ranis, the book pays homage to the influential work of Carlos Diaz-Alejandro, a luminary in the field of development economics. The essays provide a thought-provoking exploration of the intricate relationship between government intervention and market forces, shedding light on the interplay between growth, distribution, and human resource development in the region. Ranis\' insightful introduction sets the stage for a captivating journey through the economic landscape of Latin America in the 1990s, offering valuable insights into the complexities of development and the enduring relevance of Diaz-Alejandro\'s perspectives.']

['These fiscal difficulties were aggravated by high real interest rates on the order of 30 percent, which were deemed necessary to reduce pressures on the fixed exchange rate and support the stabilization plan.', 'Hence, they led to an expansion of the funding needs of the public sector and increased public debt (Berganza, 2012).', 'A series of state bailouts by the federal government in the 1990s was the result of adverse incentives for subnational fiscal restraint.', 'Brazilian states were bailed out in 1989, 1993 and 1997 4', '(Bevilaqua, 2002).2', 'The 1997 bailout under Law 9496 involved a comprehensive restructuring of state debt, where state outstanding bonds were exchanged for federal government loans.', 'The bailout entailed both up-front debt forgiveness and an interest rate subsidy on the restructured debt and was conditioned on the adoption of fiscal adjustment programs.', 'In 1998 , Brazil adopted a Fiscal Stabilization Program and reached an agreement with the IMF that sought to increase the primary surplus of federal and subnational entities , restructure the public debt , reform the budget process , and promote significant changes in the administration and social security rules', '.', 'The adoption of a Fiscal Responsibility Law (FRL) in 2000 was a key milestone.', 'Being a “Complementary Law,” it requires a qualified majority (2/3) for approval and modification and is binding for all entities of the public sector at all levels of government.', 'It introduces the use of fiscal targets, and spending and debt limits.', 'Thus, any new permanent expenditure cannot be created without reducing another expenditure item or introducing new taxes.', 'It is noteworthy that it does not specify quantitative targets or limits for the financial indicators, which are specified in separate legislation and regulations.', 'The law also strengthens the institutional fiscal framework of all areas of budget preparation, implementation, and reporting: 2monthly, 4-monthly, and annual.']

['The IDB Working Paper Series Nº IDB-WP-1185, "Public Investment and Fiscal Crisis in Brazil: Finding Culprits and Solutions," offers a comprehensive analysis of the complex interplay between fiscal rules and public investment in Brazil. Authored by Marco Bonomo, Cláudio R. Frischtak, and Paulo Ribeiro, the paper employs a multifaceted approach, including narrative analysis, case studies, interviews, empirical estimation, and model simulations to investigate the factors contributing to the fiscal crisis and propose potential solutions.

The paper delves into the significant decline in public investment in Brazil, particularly in the aftermath of the country's deepest recession, and examines the impact of existing fiscal rules at both national and subnational levels. It highlights the challenges posed by the steady increase in personnel expenditures and the limitations of current fiscal rules in preventing fiscal deterioration. Additionally, the paper explores the potential effectiveness of alternative fiscal rules in managing subnational fiscal challenges and creating fiscal space for increased investments.

Furthermore, the authors analyze the implications of the COVID-19 crisis on Brazil's fiscal prospects and draw essential lessons from empirical exercises and interviews. The paper concludes with a set of insightful recommendations aimed at addressing the fiscal crisis and revitalizing public investment in Brazil. The paper's findings and recommendations provide valuable insights for policymakers and stakeholders seeking to navigate Brazil's fiscal challenges and revitalize public investment.']

expected_output: To address its fiscal situation, Brazil needs to implement a series of measures aimed at curbing expenditures, as the tax burden is already high and further tax increases could negatively impact private investment. The current fiscal rules, which constrain government spending, may need to be redesigned to support necessary fiscal adjustments while preserving public investment. This includes addressing the significant decline in public investment, which has fallen to around 2 percent of GDP, contributing to an infrastructure deficit. Additionally, the fiscal challenges faced by subnational governments must be considered, as they account for about two-thirds of public investments. Many states are currently in a fiscal crisis, with over half unable to meet short-term liabilities, leading to substantial reductions in their investments. Therefore, a comprehensive approach that includes fiscal discipline, expenditure management, and potential reforms to fiscal rules is essential for revitalizing public investment and stabilizing the fiscal situation in Brazil [Source 4].

input.question: Quais são algumas recomendações de políticas para aumentar a confiança na América Latina?

contexts.text: ['Las políticas públicas deben procurar incrementar su potencial para aumentar la transparencia y la confianza, y a la vez mitigar sus flagrantes efectos negativos.', '10 Navegando en un mar de desconfianza La agenda de reformas para construir confianza y civismo requiere centrarse en las asimetrías de poder y de información.', 'Estas erosionan los incentivos a favor de un comportamiento confiable y cívico.', 'Progresar en esta agenda de reformas aumentará notablemente las opciones del gobierno para enfrentarse a los importantes problemas sociales y económicos de la región: lento crecimiento, alto desempleo, desigualdad, cambio climático y crisis fiscal.', 'Nueve de cada diez personas en América Latina y el Caribe no creen que se puede confiar en los otros.', 'Solo tres de cada diez confían en su gobierno y son incluso menos las que confían en las instituciones, fundamentales para la transparencia del gobierno, el Congreso y los partidos políticos.', 'En comparación con otras partes del mundo, un porcentaje mayor de ciudadanos de la región se muestra reacio a aceptar las obligaciones cívicas esenciales para construir sociedades equitativas y de rápido crecimiento.', 'Su disposición a pagar impuestos y a cumplir las leyes y regulaciones establecidas por sus gobiernos es de las más bajas del mundo.', 'Aunque intangibles y más difíciles de medir que otros problemas que afligen a la región, desde la COVID-19 y el cambio climático hasta el desempleo y la desigualdad, la desconfianza y el civismo débil demandan una atención igualmente urgente.']

['368 MELHORES GASTOS PARA MELHORES VIDAS do papel do governo, respondem que os funcionários públicos não cumprem suas promessas.', 'A segunda pergunta importante é: qual desses tipos de confiança realmente importa?', 'Onde os formuladores de políticas deveriam começar a construir confiança?', 'Uma análise criteriosa que avalie simultaneamente a associação das preferências por impostos para a educação com as quatro variáveis de confiança ( se os funcionários públicos cumprem promessas ou obedecem à lei , se as receitas arrecadadas para os pobres chegam aos pobres e se as pessoas são confiáveis em', 'geral )', 'pode ajudar a esclarecer essa questão.', 'Duas medidas de confiança se destacam: se as receitas arrecadadas para os pobres chegam efetivamente aos pobres e se as pessoas são, em geral, confiáveis.', 'Aumentar a confiança das pessoas umas nas outras não é um dos objetivos para os quais prescrições políticas já estabelecidas existem.', 'No entanto, é a outra medida de confiança — se as pessoas acreditam que as receitas arrecadadas para os pobres vão para os pobres — que maior impacto tem nas preferências políticas, além de ser a mais suscetível a intervenções pelos formuladores de políticas.', 'Se as pessoas duvidam que as políticas governamentais terão os efeitos pretendidos — e na América Latina e', 'no Caribe esse ceticismo é alto —, os governos podem responder assegurando que o oposto é verdadeiro e comunicar vigorosamente aos cidadãos evidências objetivas que comprovem esse ponto.']

['As políticas de educação, por exemplo, visam aumentar a aprendizagem dos alunos.', 'No entanto, é bem sabido que a eficácia da escolarização para a aprendizagem também depende de contribuições familiares ao processo educacional.', 'Um menor nível de confiança pode se traduzir em uma falta de confiança de que as famílias que recebem', 'os benefícios educacionais empreenderão o esforço complementar que é fundamental para o aprendizado dos alunos.', 'A baixa confiança nos outros se traduz, então, em menor apoio ao gasto com educação.', 'Da mesma forma, se as pessoas estiverem convencidas de que os cidadãos solicitarão e receberão benefícios redistributivos aos quais não têm direito, sua propensão para apoiar programas redistributivos será menor.', 'Evidências da pesquisa Barómetro das Américas 2017, que abrange todos os países da América Latina e do Caribe, e da pesquisa BID-LAPOP 2017, realizada nos sete países discutidos anteriormente, indicam um déficit de confiança na região.', 'A pesquisa do Barómetro , realizada pelo Projeto de Opinião Pública da América Latina ( LAPOP ) , da Universidade Vanderbilt , é uma das pesquisas de opinião pública mais abrangentes da região , coletando respostas de uma amostra nacionalmente representativa de todos os países da América Latina e do', 'Caribe .', 'Em 2017, como em anos anteriores, a pesquisa perguntou aos entrevistados se achavam que as pessoas em suas comunidades eram muito, mais ou menos, pouco ou nada confiáveis.']

['El libro "Confianza: La clave de la cohesión social y el crecimiento en América Latina y el Caribe" ofrece una visión integral sobre la importancia crucial de la confianza en la región. Editado por Philip Keefer y Carlos Scartascini del Banco Interamericano de Desarrollo, la obra destaca la relación entre la confianza, la cohesión social y el crecimiento económico, proporcionando un análisis detallado sobre cómo la falta de confianza puede afectar a nivel individual, institucional y económico. A través de datos y ejemplos concretos, el libro explora cómo la confianza impacta en la toma de decisiones empresariales, la efectividad de las políticas públicas, la transformación digital, la construcción de buenas políticas públicas, entre otros aspectos relevantes. Además, el libro resalta la importancia de la confianza en la superación de desafíos como la pandemia de COVID-19, así como su papel en la promoción de la democracia, el crecimiento económico, la seguridad ciudadana y la salud pública. También subraya la necesidad de informar y empoderar a las personas para aumentar la confianza en la región, destacando la importancia de la educación y la implementación de iniciativas innovadoras. En resumen, "Confianza: La clave de la cohesión social y el crecimiento en América Latina y el Caribe" ofrece una perspectiva valiosa para abordar los desafíos actuales y futuros, proporcionando un análisis detallado sobre el papel fundamental de la confianza en el desarrollo de la región.']

expected_output: Para aumentar a confiança na América Latina, as políticas públicas devem focar em aumentar a transparência e mitigar os efeitos negativos da desconfiança. É essencial abordar as asimetrías de poder e de informação, que erodem os incentivos para comportamentos confiáveis e cívicos. Avançar nessa agenda de reformas pode ajudar a enfrentar problemas sociais e econômicos significativos, como o lento crescimento e a desigualdade. Além disso, é crucial garantir que as receitas arrecadadas para os pobres realmente cheguem a eles, pois isso impacta diretamente nas preferências políticas e na confiança nas instituições. Os governos devem comunicar vigorosamente evidências objetivas que assegurem a eficácia de suas políticas, especialmente em um contexto de alto ceticismo sobre a capacidade do governo de cumprir promessas [Source 1], [Source 1], [Source 3].

input.question: What was the growth rate in LAC in 2023?

contexts.text: ['87 Chapter 4 Analysis of LAC ’s long - term growth potential LAC VC growth to match VC/ capita of other countries Deep Tech in LAC can grow 100x by replicating proven models 141x 51x VC investments in 2022 4x 10x LAC ’s potential growth spectrum The Deep Tech ecosystem', 'in LAC presents the potential for massive growth .', 'Our estimation suggests that venture capital investment in Deep Tech can grow by over 100 times in the long term.', 'China $70B USA $200B Europe $90B Israel $15B 761x Growth in the share of VC investments allocated to Deep Tech 27x 8x 9x 11x >100x Deep Tech as % of investments 126x', 'China 18% USA 24% Europe 21% Israel 60% 43x', 'LAC’s weighted potential growth average 22x This potential is driven by two factors and moderated by a third element.', 'Firstly, overall venture capital investments per capita in LAC are much smaller than in other markets.', 'To reach the per capita investment levels of China, we would need to invest 4 times more, 10 times more to reach Europe, 51 times more to reach the US, and 141 times more to reach Israel.', 'Secondly, the share of Deep Tech investments in LAC’s venture capital should grow by 8 times to 27 times to align with international standards.', 'While Deep Tech currently represents 3% of LAC’s venture capital investments, it constitutes 18% in China, 21% in Europe, 24% in the US, and an estimated 60% in Israel.', 'Lastly, it is important to recognize that STEM graduates make up a smaller proportion of our population compared to other countries, leading to reduction factors ranging from 20% to 64%.']

["The 2022 Trade and Integration Monitor offers a comprehensive analysis of trade dynamics in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) and the impact of global shocks on the region's trade performance. It delves into the factors underlying the slowdown in global trade, the impact of successive shocks on world trade, and the specific implications for LAC. The report highlights the historic slump in trade caused by the Covid-19 pandemic, which has given way to a rebound that is waning sooner and faster than expected. Additionally, it examines the impact of new shocks on global trade, including the conflict in Ukraine, the energy crisis in Europe, China's zero-Covid policy, and the tightening of monetary policies in the United States. These shocks have led to high volatility in commodity markets, new disruptions to global logistics chains, and a marked slowdown in world trade.\n\nThe report emphasizes the need to revitalize policies to shore up external competitiveness and support regional integration to ensure sustained economic growth in the region. Furthermore, it provides a detailed analysis of the dynamics of extra- and intraregional trade within specific trade blocs such as the Pacific Alliance, Central America and the Dominican Republic, Andean Community, Caribbean Community, and Southern Common Market. It also outlines the progress made on the integration agendas of these trade blocs, including digital marketplace initiatives, deep integration efforts, and external negotiations. Additionally, the report discusses the changing landscape of global trade and its impact on Latin America, highlighting the need for the region to adapt to a less dynamic and more turbulent global market. It also emphasizes the importance of effective international integration as a core ingredient in the region's economic growth and development strategy."]

['In the Eurozone, after a 5.2% rebound in 2021 and a higher-than-expected GDP increase of 5.4% in the first quarter of 2022, growth slowed to 4.1% in the second quarter and is projected to average 3.1% for the year.', 'After expanding by 8.1% in 2021 and 4.8% in the first quarter of 2022, China’s GDP growth plummeted to just 0.4% in the second quarter of 2022, and average growth of 3.2% is projected for the year.', 'In this context, after rising by 6.9% in 2021, LAC GDP growth is expected to slow to 3.5% in 2022.', 'These figures will be even lower for the region’s two largest economies, Brazil (2.8%) and Mexico (2.1%).', 'Intra- and Extraregional Exports Extraregional flows were the main driver of LA export growth, Extraregional as they account for the lion’s share of the total (85.6% in demand drove 2021).', 'however, intraregional exports—which grew 40.4% in 2021 and 33.5% in the first half of 2022—were more dynamic LAC’s export than exports outside the region, which grew 25.8% and 18.5%, performance.', 'respectively (Table 4).', 'As a result, the share of intraregional trade increased from 14.4% in 2021 to 15.8% in the first half of 2022 (Table 5).', 'The US was the partner that contributed most to LA’s export growth in both 2021 and the first half of 2022.']

['The report "Deep Tech: The New Wave" provides a compelling analysis of the burgeoning Deep Tech ecosystem in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC), showcasing its potential for transformative growth and innovation. It offers a captivating exploration of the opportunities for investors and the profound impact Deep Tech can have on addressing critical challenges and improving lives in the region. The report emphasizes the structural advantages of LAC startups and their potential to significantly influence the global Deep Tech landscape.

Furthermore, the report paints a vivid picture of the LAC Deep Tech ecosystem as a dynamic and promising frontier for investment and innovation, with the potential to drive substantial value creation and positive change. It also highlights the potential for LAC countries to leapfrog into the future by leveraging Deep Tech innovations developed elsewhere and creating new technologies that require significant innovation.

The report outlines the main challenges and opportunities for unlocking the full potential of Deep Tech in LAC, providing a roadmap for policymakers, investors, and entrepreneurs to capitalize on this emerging wave of innovation. From shared biotech labs to university accelerators, the report presents a compelling case for the development and investment in the Deep Tech ecosystem in LAC. This report is a must-read for anyone interested in the future of technology and innovation in the LAC region.']

['GDP growth in China is expected to slow from 5.2% in 2023 to 4.8% in 2024, driven by the recovery in exports, slowing further to 4.5% in 2025.', 'Growth in the Eurozone seems to have bottomed out after stagnating at 0.4% in 2023.', 'It is forecast to reach only 0.8% in 2024 and 1.2% in 2025, supported by a recovery in private consumption, real wages, and investment as financial conditions improve.', 'Finally, after expanding by 2.2% in 2023, LAC GDP is set to slow to 2.1% in 2024—with diverging growth paths in the region’s two largest economies, Brazil (3.0%) and Mexico (1.5%)—before climbing to 2.5% in 2025.', 'Weak growth among LAC’s main trading partners impacted external demand from these economies.', 'In 2023, total LAC gained imports contracted in the United States (–6.0%), China (–5.6%), market share in the EU (–5.7%), and LAC (–6.1%) (Figure 15).', 'However, the trend its main trading reversed in the second half of the year, and data for the first half of partners.', '2024 suggests a rebound in the US (3.1%) and China (1.4%), while imports continued to decline in the EU (–6.3%) and stagnated in LAC (0.6%).', 'Nevertheless, these economies’ purchases from LAC performed better than those from the rest of the world during both periods, with a few exceptions.']

["The 2024 edition of the Trade and Integration Monitor offers a compelling analysis of global trade dynamics, with a specific focus on the remarkable recovery of exports from Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC). Despite facing trade uncertainties, the region has showcased resilience by surpassing the global average, driven by a notable surge in knowledge-based services. This report emphasizes the urgent need for LAC countries to address competitiveness gaps and overcome barriers to foreign markets. It delves into the export performance of major LAC economies, highlighting strong export growth in Mexico and Brazil, and sheds light on the impact of the global coffee market on regional exports. Furthermore, the report discusses the growing importance of knowledge-based services and the need for LAC to address competitiveness lags and regulatory barriers hindering access to external markets. The Trade and Integration Monitor provides valuable insights for policymakers, businesses, and stakeholders in the LAC region, offering a detailed analysis of global trade trends and the region's trade performance. It also underscores the fragility of the region's trade recovery and the need for sustained efforts to navigate the evolving global trade landscape."]

expected_output: In 2023, the GDP growth rate for Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) was 2.2% [Source 5].

input.question: Do conditional cash transfers positively affect educational attainment?

contexts.text: ['In this study, we investigate this possibility by exploring whether benefiting from CCTs since childhood altered the academic gains from attending a more preferred secondary school in Jamaica.', 'An extensive body of research has analyzed the direct effects of CCTs on several short, medium and long-term outcomes.', 'This evidence consistently documents desirable effects on poverty reduction, school enrollment and attendance to health services (Attanasio et al., 2011; Bastagli et al., 2016;', 'Baird et al., 2013; de Walque et al., 2017; Schultz, 2004; Todd and Wolpin, 2006).', 'Studies investigating CCT effects on school learning mostly suggest null impacts ( Araujo et al . , 2017 ; Baez and Camacho , 2011 ; Baird et al . , 2014 ) , with some exceptions that find modest positive impacts ( Barham et al . , 2013 ; Stampini', 'et al . , 2018 ) .', 'More recent studies explore CCT effects on longer - term educational attainment , labor market outcomes , and resilience against poverty among individuals who were treated during childhood ( Araujo and Macours , 2021 ; Attanasio et al . , 2021 ; Barham et al . , 2017 , 2018', '; Parker and Vogl , 2023 ; Molina Mill´an et al . , 2020 ; Oconnor , 2024).2', 'A related strand of growing literature has engaged in experimenting with complementary interventions to potentially enhance the effectiveness of cash transfers.', 'This Cash-Plus approach notes that the common conditionality of school attendance or regular healthcare visits embedded in CCTs, might not be enough to bolster early childhood development.', 'This because many critical behaviors that mediate appropriate child development, like balanced and nutritious feeding or stimulation to promote socio-cognitive growth, are mostly dependent on (private) parental practices rather than on access to education and health services.']

['The Inter-American Development Bank's working paper, "Cash Transfers, Poverty, and Inequality in Latin America and the Caribbean," offers a comprehensive analysis of non-contributory cash transfer systems in the region. Authored by Marco Stampini, Nadin Medellín, and Pablo Ibarrarán, the paper delves into the factors that hinder the effectiveness of these programs in reducing poverty and inequality. The study evaluates the size and targeting of cash transfer programs, shedding light on their impact on poverty and inequality.

The paper reveals that despite the significant reach of cash transfer programs, their impact on poverty and inequality is limited due to the small size of transfers and historical under-coverage of the population living in poverty. It highlights that only 55% of the population in poverty benefits from these programs, and 41% of people in households receiving non-contributory transfers are above the poverty line. The study also identifies the countries that have achieved the highest scores in terms of program effectiveness, providing valuable insights for policymakers.

The authors offer policy recommendations, emphasizing the need to intensify efforts to increase coverage among the poor and recertify eligibility for transfer programs more frequently. They advocate for the use of modern poverty mapping techniques and active searches to create more efficient income protection systems that address both structural and transient poverty.

Overall, the paper provides a compelling analysis of the challenges and opportunities in non-contributory cash transfer systems in Latin America and the Caribbean, offering valuable insights for policymakers, researchers, and development practitioners.']

['An important question, in Honduras and other resource-constrained contexts, is whether the imposition and monitoring of conditions increases outcomes beyond that of an unconditional cash transfer.', 'Cash alone may increase demand for schooling and/or health services via income effects, but a CCT decreases opportunity costs and could further occasion a substitution effect (Baird et al., 2014).', 'Whether this occurs is an empirical question, analyzed in a growing body of papers.1', 'It has been most compellingly studied in randomized experiments with unconditional and conditional treatment arms.2', 'However , none of this evidence is from Latin America , where researchers have relied on non - experimental — but perhaps exogenous — variation in the enforcement of conditions.3 In Ecuador and Mexico , the effects on school enrollment were lower when some households believed that the cash transfers', 'were unconditional , due to quirks in program implementation ( de Brauw & Hoddinott , 2011 ; Schady & Araujo , 2008 ) .', 'In the Ecuador experiment, however, the effects on child labor were the same, regardless of households’ beliefs about education conditionalities (Edmonds & Schady, 2012).', 'In Colombia, health conditions were only enforced among children born before mothers registered for the CCT 1 Baird et al.', '(2014) review this literature on education, including the studies cited below, and find that effects on education enrollment are positively related to a qualitative index of the conditionalities’ strength.', '2 Adding school-related conditions increased the impact of transfers on drop-out rates in Malawi (Baird, McIntosh, & Özler, 2011).', 'In Burkina Faso, conditions increased school enrollments, but only among subgroups of girls, younger children, and lower-ability children (Akresh, de Walque, & Kazianga, 2013).', 'The same experiment found that that health center visits only increased substantially among young children in the presence of conditions (Akresh et al., in press).']

['The paper "Do Education and Health Conditions Matter in a Large Cash Transfer? Evidence from a Honduran Experiment" by Fiorella Benedetti, Pablo Ibarrarán, and Patrick McEwan, presents a comprehensive analysis of the impact of a large cash transfer program in Honduras. The study evaluates the "Bono 10,000" experiment, a conditional cash transfer initiative aimed at poor households, comparing its effects with an earlier experiment, "PRAF-II," to assess the influence of education and health conditions on outcomes such as school enrollment, child labor participation, and health service use.

The findings reveal that the Bono 10,000 program, despite offering larger transfers, yielded smaller overall effects on school enrollment, child labor, and health service utilization compared to the previous experiment. The authors attribute this to the varying application of conditions within households, particularly in relation to the number and age of eligible children. The study provides valuable insights into the role of conditionalities in cash transfer programs, shedding light on their impact on education, child labor, and health outcomes.

This research contributes to the growing body of literature on conditional cash transfers, offering important implications for policymakers and practitioners involved in social protection programs. The study's rigorous evaluation and insightful findings make it a valuable resource for understanding the effectiveness of large cash transfer initiatives in improving education and health outcomes for vulnerable populations.']

['Box 1 – Impacts of conditional cash transfers in Latin America and the Caribbean Conditional Cash Transfer Programs ( CCTPs ) reached the very poorest and met the primary short - term objective of increasing spending and reducing current poverty ( Fiszbein and Schady 2009 ; Bastagli et al .', '2016 ) .', 'These programs also achieved the expected changes in behavior, reducing child labor (Galiani and McEwan 2013; Edmonds and Schady 2012; Levy 2006) and increasing demand for services that build human capital.', 'Use of health services rose ( by a range of 6.3 percentage points in Nicaragua to 33 in Colombia ) ( Fiszbein and Schady 2009 ) and in some cases led to improvements in children ’s anthropometric development ( Barber and Gertler 2008 ) and reduced morbidity ( Gaarder ,', 'Glassman , and Todd 2010 ) .', 'CCTPs also increased school enrollment and attendance ( by a range of 0.5 percentage points in Jamaica to 12.8 in Nicaragua ( Fiszbein and Schady 2009 ) , as well as school progression ( from six months to one year in Mexico , after three to five years of exposure', ') .', 'Rigorous impact evaluations show that CCTPs have positive short - term impacts on child development ( motor development , cognitive development , and language ) in Mexico ( Fernald et al . 2008 ) , on language in Ecuador ( Fernald and Hidrobo 2011 ; Paxson and Schady 2010 )', ', and on cognitive and behavioral indicators in Nicaragua ( Macours , Schady , and Vakis 2012 ) .', 'Evidence of impact on learning is somewhat weaker (Fiszbein and Schady 2009; Saavedra and García 2012), possibly as a result of the poor quality of educational offerings.', 'Stampini et al.']

['The working paper "Can Conditional Cash Transfers Alter the Effectiveness of other Human Capital Development Policies?" by Diether W. Beuermann, Andrea Ramos Bonilla, and Marco Stampini, delves into the potential impact of conditional cash transfers (CCTs) on the effectiveness of other human capital development policies. Focusing on the Jamaican context, the study investigates whether receiving CCTs since childhood influenced the academic gains from attending a more preferred public secondary school. Using a double regression discontinuity design, the paper uncovers causal associations and examines the interaction effects between CCTs and preferred school attendance on academic performance.\n\nThe findings reveal that while CCT participation did not directly impact learning outcomes, boys exposed to CCTs experienced significantly lower gains from attending preferred schools compared to their peers who did not receive CCTs. This highlights the importance of considering both the direct and potential indirect effects of CCTs on other interventions. The study provides valuable insights into the interaction between different interventions and their impact on outcomes, using nationally institutionalized policies and full-population administrative data. This research has significant implications for policymakers and stakeholders involved in designing and implementing human capital development programs, particularly in the context of conditional cash transfers and education policies.']

expected_output: Conditional cash transfers (CCTs) have shown mixed effects on educational attainment. While they have been effective in increasing school enrollment and attendance, the direct impact on learning outcomes is less clear. Studies indicate that CCTs can lead to positive short-term effects on behaviors related to education, such as reducing child labor and increasing demand for schooling and health services [Source 5]. However, evidence regarding their impact on actual learning outcomes is inconsistent, with many studies suggesting null effects [Source 1]. Some exceptions do report modest positive impacts on educational attainment [Source 1]. Overall, while CCTs can enhance access to education, their effectiveness in improving educational quality and learning outcomes remains a topic of ongoing research.

input.question: Define Trust

contexts.text: ['Without trust, people would stop at every intersection, check the maintenance records of every elevator, seek multiple medical opinions for simple ailments, evaluate the approval process for each medication they take, and rely only on cash for market transactions.', 'In the parlance of economists, trust reduces transaction costs.', 'Mistrust is a significant obstacle to development (see Chapters 3–6).', 'However, unlike other determinants of development, trust is an intangible, psychological phenomenon.', 'Intangible determinants of economic development are inherently more challenging to measure than tangible 27', '28 TRUST: THE KEY TO SOCIAL COHESION AND GROWTH determinants, such as infrastructure.', 'Similarly, everyone is familiar with how engineering and construction transform public investment into public infrastructure, but there is less understanding of the processes that give rise to high or low trust.', 'This chapter discusses advances in the measurement of trust and trustworthiness and in understanding the complicated pathways through which individual experience affects trust both contemporaneously and over time, even across generations.', 'Though interpersonal trust is the core concern of this book, its effects radiate through all aspects of society, including trust in institutions and government, which itself significantly impacts development outcomes (see Chapter 4).', 'The dynamics of institutional and interpersonal trust are similar and are explored in the last section of the chapter.', 'How to Measure Trust Measuring trust and trustworthiness is arduous (Bauer and Freitag, 2017).', 'The first challenge is to define it (Uslaner, 2016).', 'In this book, trust refers to the belief that others will not act opportunistically.', 'This is related to, but narrower than, definitions of trust that link it to the concept of social capital.', 'It places more emphasis than others on the importance of reliance: trust requires putting oneself in a position in which others can act opportunistically to one’s disadvantage.']

['For example , old master dealers who authenticate , valuate , receive in consignment , or bid in auctions for major works of art on behalf of collectors ( sometimes private collectors , sometimes institutional ones , like museums and art academies ) seldom sign receipts or contracts with their', 'client collectors ; they know that one faux pas would force them out of business for good .', 'Trust (fr Old English treowe, faithful), confidence (fr Lat conf/dere, to place faith), and credit (fr. Lat.', 'credere, to believe) are, to paraphrase Prospero (Shakespeare 1973, The Tempest, act 4, sc. I), such stuff as dreams of cooperation and reciprocity are made.', 'Ethics and the Law There are many manifestations of social trust , like those associated with the expectation of reliable accounting , the ethical conduct of ( ethical ) business , and the pursuit of transparency in the marketplace , which are addressed in other chapters of this book Another', 'social form of trust is the generalized belief that government pursues the common good and that it has a monopoly of legitimate force .', 'When this is in doubt because of perceived asymmetry in the workings of the market, the functioning of government, or unpunished acts of rebellion or common delinquency, a fiction is uncovered: the government does not have the strength and legitimacy it invokes.', 'Asymmetries can result from government action, like some of the welfare state policies of the postwar period that redounded in the debilitation of the rule of law through their encroachment on private property rights.', 'But, more perniciously, high and variable inflation as much as deep, protracted recessions can profoundly distort social and economic values and standards in society, impelling some sectors into desperation while enriching others.', 'It is difficult for the public to trust government authorities and institutions, current and future, when macroeconomic or political mismanagement is the direct determinant of their predicaments.']

['Trust is both result and constitutive element of decisions and actions that simultaneously take into account self - interest and the interest of others.6 Controls and reviews , although necessary , are expensive substitutes for trust , and it is their cost that usually makes them limited in scope and', 'depth .', 'That is why it is customary in business to speak of " good - faith efforts " to comply with agreements , " full and fair disclosure " when dealing with information , or a " general willingness " not to take undue advantage of counterparts when conditions change ,', 'thus acknowledging that no piece of legislation , contractual clause , enforcement practice , or human intervention will be infallibly problem - free ( Hosmer 1997)7 In addition to rules and regulations on disclosure , adequate procedures , accountability , and transparency , building up confidence requires the agency of', 'trustworthy people .', 'This means that professional actors in the market not only should be competent in their respective capacities but also should be aware of the trust in their activities and functions and the moral commitment to live up to such trust.', 'Individuals, particularly professionals, frequently encounter discretionary space in their activities as, by definition, no rule can predict all outcomes.', 'For example, the accountant, the attorney, and the market analyst regularly have to make assumptions and representations that often cannot be verified by the client at the time of making an investment decision.', 'Or, more seriously, they may have to take actions that cannot wait for the approval of their clients.', 'This leads to a new level of analysis, beyond the consumption of confidence and even the individual production of confidence.', 'If confidence were conceived as a public good in economic terms — that is , as a good from which nobody could be excluded and that could be consumed by any economic agent without reducing or impairing its consumption by others — then the production of confidence would require the', 'collective effort of all participants in the system ( Enderle 2000 , 2002 ) .']

['"Focus on Capital: New Approaches to Developing Latin American Capital Markets" provides a comprehensive analysis of the challenges and opportunities in Latin American and Caribbean capital markets. The book offers strategic initiatives and policy recommendations to foster market development in the region, emphasizing the crucial role of local capital market development in promoting economic growth, reducing financial instability, and facilitating the efficient allocation of resources. It delves into critical issues affecting the region\'s financial markets, offering practical operational insights and theoretical grounding. The narrative discusses the impact of international events on the region\'s capital markets, such as the emerging market crises and the role of mature market developments in influencing market access. Furthermore, the book addresses the factors affecting market development, including the impact of financial crises, the role of crossover institutional investors, and the increasing role of the Internet on capital market activities in Latin America. It also discusses the need for enhanced regulatory frameworks, broadening the role of market institutions and actors, and supporting regional efforts for capital market integration. The book provides a valuable resource for understanding and addressing the challenges and opportunities in the region\'s capital markets, offering policymakers a long-term vision and strategic plan for market development. It also highlights the recent legislative initiatives and private efforts in Latin America, such as the Novo Mercado initiative in Brazil, and their impact on corporate governance and capital market development.']

expected_output: Trust is defined as the belief that others will not act opportunistically, which emphasizes reliance on others despite the potential for disadvantage. It is an intangible, psychological phenomenon that plays a crucial role in reducing transaction costs in economic interactions. Without trust, individuals would need to verify every aspect of their transactions, leading to inefficiencies and increased costs. Trust is essential for social cohesion and economic development, as it influences not only interpersonal relationships but also trust in institutions and government, which significantly impacts development outcomes [Source 1].

input.question: Sobre o que trata o Livro? "Expanding Opportunities: Policies for Gender Equality and Inclusion”?

contexts.text: ['As desigualdades baseadas em grupos instigam a mobilização e a defesa de direitos e, se não forem remediadas, podem gerar conflito e violência, especialmente em países com alto grau de desigualdade e diversidade étnica (Stewart, 2001; Easterly, 2002).', 'A resposta deve vir sob a forma de políticas de inclusão social que utilizem as ferramentas de diálogo, a resolução de controvérsias e a negociação.', 'Também são necessários processos de aprendizagem social que eduquem todos os cidadãos quanto ao valor da diversidade e às riquezas a serem obtidas com o respeito às diferenças.', 'A natureza cumulativa da exclusão baseada em gênero, etnia e raça tem aumentado as lacunas de bem-estar na região, especialmente para as mulheres.', 'A política social deve nivelar o campo de ação em favor das mulheres nos grupos excluídos.', 'Para tanto, os discursos sobre desenvolvimento e defesa de direitos devem preencher a lacuna criada por essas diferentes circunstâncias.', 'Os problemas', 'INTRODUÇÃO: INCLUSÃO SOCIAL NA AMÉRICA LATINA 26 de discriminação racial e étnica devem se converter em peças centrais na agenda de igualdade de gênero, e as questões de gênero devem assumir maior importância nas agendas dos grupos socialmente excluídos.', 'Uma agenda de igualdade de gênero calcada nos objetivos de inclusão social enfatizará a redução da pobreza.']

market , unlock the potential of women - led enterprises , and break the glass ceilings that have limited women ’s advancement into leadership', 'roles .']

['In recent years, Latin America and the Caribbean have experienced a significant shift towards social inclusion and affirmative action initiatives. This transformation has been driven by a growing awareness of social issues at international summits, the need to address structural inequalities exacerbated by globalization, and the demand for more participatory processes and social rights from citizens. Governments in countries such as Colombia, Brazil, Mexico, and Peru have been at the forefront of pioneering policy initiatives aimed at promoting various aspects of social inclusion, from affirmative action programs to comprehensive anti-discrimination legislation.\n\nThis wave of social activism and policy reform signifies a fundamental rethinking of development paradigms and a commitment to addressing historical inequalities. International development organizations are also embracing the goal of social inclusion, emphasizing the understanding of the causes of poverty and inequality and implementing measures to combat them. The shift towards social inclusion represents a significant step towards building a more equitable and inclusive society in Latin America and the Caribbean. This shift has also been reflected in efforts to address the challenges faced by marginalized communities, such as the development of capacity-building programs in Afro-descendant communities in Honduras and Guatemala. These initiatives aim to empower these communities to address the factors perpetuating their marginalization and drive their own development.']

['Uma agenda de inclusão social com uma perspectiva de gênero promoverá a identidade cultural dos grupos excluídos desafiando, ao mesmo tempo, normas e comportamentos culturais que relegam a mulher a um plano inferior.', 'Nos Estados Unidos, o movimento pelos direitos civis impulsionou a campanha pelo voto feminino (O’Connor, 2003).', 'Na América Latina, o movimento de mulheres, com sua experiência e suas conquistas, poderia fomentar a agenda de inclusão social e propiciar o amplo apoio necessário.', 'O principal desafio', 'para os governos da região é converter a inclusão social em uma prioridade básica na política de desenvolvimento nacional (e nas dotações orçamentárias do governo).', 'Os organismos de desenvolvimento internacionais, por sua vez, devem incorporar plenamente os objetivos de inclusão social às suas operações.', 'Ambos devem ser corroborados por evidência que mostre o valor instrumental da consecução dos objetivos de inclusão social e que forneça informações confiáveis sobre o que funciona, como funciona e quanto custa.', 'Este capítulo mostrou que há uma grande riqueza de experiências na América Latina nas diferentes frentes de combate à exclusão por motivos de gênero, etnia, raça, deficiências e HIV/aids.', 'Cada uma dessas frentes deve ser analisada de forma mais sistemática, com base nas lições que pode oferecer em prol da promoção de uma agenda de inclusão mais abrangente.']

['"Development in the Americas: Expanding Opportunities" is a groundbreaking report that delves into the crucial issues of gender equality and LGBTQ+ inclusion in Latin America and the Caribbean. Edited by M. Caridad Araujo, Samuel Berlinski, Mariano Bosch, and Verónica Frisancho, the report offers a comprehensive roadmap for creating more inclusive societies. It highlights the significant progress made in the region, such as increased life expectancy for women, improved gender gaps in education, and growing social acceptance of diverse sexual orientations and gender identities. However, it also brings attention to persistent challenges, including the underrepresentation of women in leadership positions, stagnant gender wage gaps, and prevalent gender-based violence.\n\nThe report emphasizes the economic imperative of achieving gender equality and fostering diversity, as it can significantly improve economic outcomes for countries, cities, and firms. It provides a structured approach to public policy, focusing on foundational policies, economic opportunities, and political and institutional reforms. This publication serves as a call to action for governments, civil society leaders, the private sector, and citizens across the region, offering evidence-based recommendations for informed decision-making and concerted efforts to build more equitable and inclusive societies. This comprehensive and well-researched report is a must-read for anyone interested in understanding the changes in the lives of individuals in Latin America and the Caribbean and should become the go-to resource for every policymaker in the region.']

expected_output: The book "Expanding Opportunities: Policies for Gender Equality and Inclusion" addresses critical issues of gender equality and LGBTQ+ inclusion in Latin America and the Caribbean. It highlights the progress made in the region, such as improved gender gaps in education and increased life expectancy for women, while also pointing out ongoing challenges like underrepresentation of women in leadership, stagnant gender wage gaps, and high rates of gender-based violence. The report emphasizes that achieving gender equality is not only a matter of social justice but also an economic necessity, as it can significantly enhance economic outcomes for countries and firms. It provides a structured approach to public policy focused on foundational policies, economic opportunities, and political reforms, aiming to create more inclusive societies through evidence-based recommendations for governments and civil society leaders [Source 2].

input.question: what is carbon pricing finance?

contexts.text: ['All countries, especially developing ones, face urgent development needs: some need to finance infrastructure deployment, health services, social assistance and inequality reduction.', 'A growing literature argues that carbon taxes are an appropriate way of financing these needs.', 'Carbon Pricing as a Fiscal Instrument In deciding what production factors to tax to finance the functioning of the government and investments in public goods, finance ministers have several options, including taxing wages, capital or investment, land, energy, or imports.', 'Carbon prices could provide substantial revenues to government.', 'In 2015, auctions in existing carbon markets and taxes labeled as carbon taxes provided governments with an estimated $26 billion (Vivid Economics, 2016).', 'But the potential is much higher than that.', 'Domestic carbon pricing consistent with the 2 ° C target ( from 20 $ to 120$/tCO2 in 2020 depending on the model ) could provide about $ 2 trillion per year to governments globally , and would be enough to finance infrastructure that would close existing access gaps in developing', 'countries for water , sanitation , electricity , and telecommunication , even without international transfers ( Jakob et al . , 2016 ) .', 'In 60 out of 87 developing countries analyzed in a world bank study, a $30/tCO2 domestic tax would provide the government with enough resources to more than double current spending on social assistance (Hallegatte et al., 2016).', 'Taxes on fossil fuel energy may be much easier to administrate than other fiscal instruments, with smaller negative impacts on economy activity.', 'In the United States, for example, tax collection covering 80 percent of CO2 emissions from fossil fuel consumption could be accomplished by monitoring fewer than 3,000 points, mainly refineries, coal mines, and natural gas fields (Metcalf and Weisbach, 2009).', 'This contrasts with dozen of ['The document "Climate Policies in Latin America and the Caribbean: Success Stories and Challenges in the Fight Against Climate Change" provides a comprehensive analysis of the region\'s climate policies, emphasizing the urgency of addressing climate change and the need for robust policy interventions. It delves into the historical context of climate change, the impact of anthropogenic activities, and the challenges faced by policymakers. The executive summary offers an overview of the critical issues addressed, including the historical perspective of climate change, the impact on vulnerable sectors, decarbonization strategies, fiscal instruments for decarbonization, renewable energy, and the politics of climate change. It also highlights the need for a green post-Covid-19 recovery and the role of the middle class in driving climate policies. The document sheds light on the economic impacts of climate change, emphasizing the need for informed and decisive action to address the challenges posed by climate change. It provides a compelling narrative that encourages further exploration of the document\'s detailed insights and recommendations. The report also discusses the impact of climate change on agriculture, water resources, energy, and public health, highlighting the need for adaptation strategies and sustainable development pathways. Additionally, it emphasizes the role of finance and planning ministries in integrating climate policies into their mandates and the potential for climate policies to achieve growth and social development in the region. The document also provides specific examples of successful climate policies and initiatives in the region, showcasing the potential for sustainable land management and decarbonization. It also addresses the challenges and limitations of carbon taxes in the region, highlighting the need for compensation mechanisms and comprehensive policy frameworks to ensure the effectiveness of carbon pricing. Overall, the document presents a thorough analysis of climate policies in Latin America and the Caribbean, offering valuable insights and recommendations for addressing the complex and pressing issue of climate change in the region.']

['When confronted with this cost, emitters are expected to modify their decisions by either shifting toward sustainable alternatives or embracing efficient production and consumption patterns, thereby reducing GHG emissions to socially optimal levels (McKitrick, 2016).34 Carbon pricing can be done in several ways.', 'However , the most common are emission trading schemes ( ETS ) and carbon taxes.35 The former , also known as cap - and - trade systems , set a cap on the amount or intensity of emissions and involve the trade of allowances auctioned by the government which ,', 'in aggregate , account for the cap .', 'In general, firms with high decarbonization costs try to acquire these allowances in the market; in this sense, their price is defined by supply and demand.', 'On the other hand , carbon taxes work the opposite way : they directly fix the price of GHG emissions , usually as a function of the carbon content of a certain fossil fuel , while letting the market determine their amount ( Narassimhan et al . , 2017 )', '.', 'In theory, carbon taxes take the form of Pigouvian taxes.', 'Their size should be such that it drives GHG emissions toward their optimal level.', 'To do so, their rates should be uniform across sectors and products and have a wide base.', 'Besides curbing emissions, carbon taxes generate fiscal revenues that can be reinvested in the economy.', 'This is what is known as the double-dividend hypothesis (Timilsinas, 2018).', 'Carbon pricing has been recognized as a popular mechanism to promote decarbonization, especially after the 2015 Paris Agreement (World Bank, 2019b; Gillingham and Stock, 2018).', 'Of 185 parties that committed to reduce their GHG emissions by 2030, up to 85 are considering using carbon pricing to achieve their goals.']

['The paper "Climate Policies and Nationally Determined Contributions: Reconciling the Needed Ambition with the Political Economy" offers a comprehensive analysis of the challenges and opportunities in aligning climate policies with social and political realities. It emphasizes the importance of designing climate policies and Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) that not only aim for zero-net emissions but also consider the social and political implications of such reforms. The authors review the literature on how policymakers can align climate policies with long-term decarbonization goals and create coalitions of supporters to ensure successful implementation. The paper also delves into the political economy of climate policies, acknowledging the potential for certain policies to create losers and proposes approaches to mitigate negative impacts, such as compensatory measures and complementary policies. Additionally, the paper highlights the potential for climate policies to align with non-climate objectives, such as funding social assistance and infrastructure investment, to garner support and minimize disruptions. The analysis offers valuable insights for policymakers and stakeholders involved in climate action, providing a roadmap for reconciling the ambition of climate policies with the social and political realities.']

['All of this is compared with what has been delivered in practice, regarding emission reductions, boosting innovation, and adoption of green technologies.', 'The results of the interviews are also checked against Article 6 of the Paris Agreement, and the regulation on voluntary cooperation between parties to agree to transfer reductions between countries.', '07', '1.2 Carbon Pricing Deﬁnition Carbon pricing instruments are economic policies for promoting the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions resulting from the use and consumption of fossil fuels and their derivatives, by internalizing the cost of their emission.', 'The theory is to create conditions for actors, such as companies or automobile users, to internalize the costs they generate for society through the pollution caused by their activity (Pigou, 1932).', 'In this sense, carbon pricing incentivizes reduction, and potentially elimination, of emissions by encouraging adoption of consumption and production alternatives where the cost per ton avoided is lower than the price imposed (Haites et al., 2023).', 'It is important to note that the amount of the tax is decisive; when the cost of reducing emissions is higher than the price imposed, it is more convenient to pay the tax than to reduce emissions.', 'Because they incentivize the cheapest emission reduction options, carbon prices have been described as an economically efcient or "cost-effective" mechanism (Nordhaus, 1992;', 'Goulder and Shein, 2013; Haites et al., 2023).', 'Of the variety of carbon pricing instruments that exist, this analysis focuses on the three most common: carbon taxes (also called green taxes); emissions trading systems; and emissions credit markets.', 'The term "carbon market" can refer to both emission allowance and emission credit markets.', 'Other ﬁscal and economic instruments which can create incentives to reduce or increase greenhouse gas emissions –though not covered in detail in this document- include subsidies, taxes on fuels not deﬁned by their emissions content, or taxes on cars based their cylinder capacity.']

['The study "Expectations of Economy and Finance Ministries on Carbon Pricing and Evidence of Their Effectiveness" provides a comprehensive analysis of the critical role of carbon pricing mechanisms in addressing climate change in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) region. Through insightful semi-structured interviews with 12 ministries of finance, the report sheds light on their expectations, objectives, and challenges related to the implementation of carbon pricing instruments. Additionally, the study delves into the empirical evidence on the effectiveness of these mechanisms in achieving environmental and fiscal goals.

Key findings from the interviews reveal that the primary objective of carbon pricing in the region is to contribute to environmental policy by incentivizing emissions reductions and promoting cleaner technologies. However, the study highlights that the effectiveness of existing carbon taxes in achieving these objectives has not been evaluated. Furthermore, the report emphasizes the need for a comprehensive approach to climate policy, acknowledging that carbon pricing alone may not be sufficient to drive the structural transformations required for achieving carbon neutrality.

The study also addresses the challenges and barriers faced by the region's finance and economy ministries in implementing carbon pricing, providing valuable insights for policymakers and stakeholders. Overall, the findings underscore the importance of a holistic and strategic approach to carbon pricing, considering its environmental, fiscal, and transformative impacts. The study's comprehensive analysis offers valuable recommendations for enhancing the effectiveness of carbon pricing mechanisms and advancing climate action in the LAC region.']

expected_output: Carbon pricing finance refers to the economic policies designed to promote the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions by internalizing the costs associated with their emissions. This is achieved through mechanisms such as carbon taxes and emissions trading systems, which create financial incentives for emitters to reduce their greenhouse gas output. By imposing a price on carbon emissions, these instruments encourage companies and consumers to shift towards cleaner technologies and practices, thereby contributing to environmental policy goals. Additionally, carbon pricing can generate substantial fiscal revenues for governments, which can be reinvested in public goods and services, addressing urgent development needs such as infrastructure and social assistance. For instance, a domestic carbon tax could provide significant resources to enhance government spending on social programs and infrastructure in developing countries, potentially doubling current social assistance expenditures in many cases [Source 1].

['Enrique V. Iglesias' book "Cambio y Crecimiento en América Latina: Ideas y Acciones" offers a comprehensive analysis of the economic and social evolution of Latin America and the Caribbean. Drawing from his extensive experience as the former President of the Inter-American Development Bank, Iglesias provides a unique perspective on the region's challenges and opportunities. The book delves into the collapse of the post-war economic model, the strategies adopted by countries in response to the changing international economic landscape, and the role of the Inter-American Development Bank in addressing the diverse and evolving development needs of its member countries.

Iglesias' personal experiences and thought-provoking analysis make this book a compelling resource for policymakers, scholars, and anyone interested in understanding the complex dynamics of development in Latin America and the Caribbean. The book not only provides a historical perspective but also offers valuable lessons for the future, emphasizing the importance of market-oriented policies and effective macroeconomic management, as well as the need for ambitious educational reforms to bridge the gap with other regions.

Furthermore, Iglesias highlights the critical role of education and culture in driving economic growth and social equity, shedding light on the imperative of investing in human capital and fostering a culture of responsibility and transparency. "Cambio y Crecimiento en América Latina: Ideas y Acciones" is an essential read for anyone seeking a deeper understanding of the development challenges and opportunities in the region.']

Established in 1959, the BID has continuously evolved to address the economic challenges and opportunities faced by its member countries, extending its role beyond traditional banking to accelerate the overall development of the region.

The BID's commitment to innovation, pragmatism, and efficiency has been evident since its early years, as it has supported a wide range of projects and programs contributing significantly to the economic and social progress of the region. ["The Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) was established in 1959 with a noble mission to address the economic challenges faced by Latin America and the Caribbean. The region had been grappling with the aftermath of the Great Depression and the consequences of heavy reliance on primary product exports. The subsequent strategy of import substitution industrialization (ISI) brought about economic, social, and political modernization, leading to a period of high economic growth between 1950 and 1970. However, ISI also led to persistent imbalances in external accounts and chronic currency devaluations, culminating in the external debt crisis of 1982.\n\nThe establishment of the IDB was a pivotal step in strengthening and implementing the best aspects of this development strategy. The bank's creation faced opposition from various quarters, including Wall Street and large institutional investors. Despite these obstacles, the IDB's formation represented a significant shift in the region's approach to economic development and cooperation. This narrative sets the stage for the IDB's role in shaping the economic and social landscape of Latin America and the Caribbean, highlighting the bank's significance in the region's history and its potential for future impact."]

['El libro "Seguridad vial en América Latina y el Caribe: tras un decenio de acción y perspectivas para una movilidad más segura" ofrece una visión integral sobre la situación actual de la seguridad vial en la región. Editado por un grupo de expertos, el libro proporciona un análisis detallado, experiencias significativas y recomendaciones para el futuro. La primera parte del libro presenta datos clave, enfoques de género y un resumen de los logros alcanzados en la última década en materia de seguridad vial. La segunda parte se centra en las experiencias y aprendizajes de este período, abordando la gestión de la seguridad vial, la infraestructura y movilidad seguras, vehículos más seguros, usuarios de vías más seguros y la atención a las víctimas. Finalmente, la tercera parte del libro plantea un nuevo decenio de acción, ofreciendo recomendaciones de política pública para la región. Además, el libro destaca el impacto positivo de la implementación de un sistema efectivo de inspección vehicular, como se evidencia en el caso de Costa Rica, donde se logró una reducción significativa de incidentes viales causados por fallas mecánicas. Este enfoque innovador y colaborativo proporciona una valiosa contribución para comprender, mejorar y promover la seguridad en las vías de América Latina y el Caribe.']

['RESUMEN Los accidentes de tránsito constituyen un importante problema de salud pública en América Latina y el Caribe, con un balance de aproximadamente 110.000 muertes y más de 5 millones de heridos al año.', 'Estas tragedias tienen implicaciones económicas de gran alcance y le cuestan a la región entre el 3 y el 5% de su producto interno bruto.', 'Un gran número de accidentes de tránsito se puede atribuir a una variedad de conductas no seguras, como la distracción al volante, el exceso de velocidad y la incapacidad de conducir debido al consumo de alcohol o de drogas.', 'A través del entendimiento de los factores cognitivos y sociales que influyen en estas conductas, las ciencias del comportamiento a menudo ofrecen perspectivas valiosas para la elaboración de intervenciones y estrategias efectivas dirigidas a promover la seguridad vial.', 'Este informe se centra en los sesgos conductuales y cognitivos que hacen que los accidentes sean tan habituales en América Latina y el Caribe ; en iniciativas implementadas en todo el mundo que emplean perspectivas conductuales y podrían resultar beneficiosas para la región , y en intervenciones conductuales implementadas en', 'América Latina y el Caribe para aumentar la seguridad vial .', 'Los autores desean agradecer a la División de Transporte del Banco Interamericano de Desarrollo por su valiosa contribución en el intercambio de ideas e información que hizo posible esta publicación.', 'Todas las ilustraciones incluidas en este informe son una representación fiel de la intervención a la que se refieren.']

['El informe "Cómo aumentar la SEGURIDAD VIAL en América Latina y el Caribe: Lecciones de la economía del comportamiento" ofrece una visión integral sobre la problemática de los accidentes de tránsito en la región. Con un promedio de 110,000 muertes y 5 millones de heridos al año, los accidentes viales representan un desafío de salud pública y tienen un impacto económico significativo, costando a la región entre el 3 y el 5% de su producto interno bruto. El informe se centra en la influencia de los factores cognitivos y sociales en las conductas que contribuyen a estos accidentes, ofreciendo valiosas perspectivas sobre cómo abordar este problema. Además, destaca la importancia de comprender y abordar los sesgos cognitivos que influyen en la toma de decisiones de los conductores, peatones y ciclistas. Ofrece recomendaciones basadas en la economía del comportamiento para abordar estos desafíos y promover conductas más seguras en las carreteras de América Latina y el Caribe.']

expected_output: Para reducir las muertes por accidentes de tránsito en América Latina y el Caribe, es fundamental adoptar un enfoque integral que incluya intervenciones innovadoras y educación sobre seguridad vial. Esto implica una vigilancia más estricta del cumplimiento de las normas de tráfico y la incorporación de tecnologías emergentes para mejorar la seguridad en las carreteras [Source 4]. Además, es crucial entender y abordar los sesgos cognitivos que influyen en las decisiones de los conductores, peatones y ciclistas, lo que puede ayudar a promover comportamientos más seguros [Source 4]. La implementación de un sistema efectivo de inspección vehicular también ha demostrado ser eficaz, como se evidenció en Costa Rica, donde se logró una reducción significativa de incidentes viales causados por fallas mecánicas [Source 3]. Finalmente, se deben desarrollar políticas públicas que prioricen la infraestructura segura y accesible para todos los usuarios de las vías [Source 2].
